awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: IsoBank: A centralized repository for isotopic data
awd_abstract_narration:
Stable isotopes encode and integrate the origin of matter; their analysis offers tremendous potential to address questions across diverse scientific disciplines. The broad applicability of stable isotopes, coupled with advancements in high-throughput analysis, have created a scientific field that is growing exponentially, and generating data at a rate paralleling the explosive rise of DNA sequencing and genomics. Centralized data repositories, such as GenBank, have become central in archiving information, and the analytics offered by these resources are revolutionizing science and everyday life. But to date, a centralized database for the management of isotopic data does not exist. The absence of such a resource has impeded research progress through the unnecessary duplication of effort, restricted the near-boundless application of stable isotopes, and curtailed the exchange of information among scientists within and among disciplines. The creation of a centralized database for stable isotopes would be more than a silo for data; it would be a dynamic resource to unite disciplinary fields and answer pressing questions in agriculture, animal sciences, archaeology, anthropology, ecology, medicine, nutrition, physiology, paleontology, forensics, earth and planetary sciences. We believe that such a centralized database would accelerate and enhance such global and multi-disciplinary endeavors, thus broaden the reach of isotope science.

This project brings together a multidisciplinary team of analytical experts and scientists who produce and interpret isotope data with database architects and website developers in a series of workshops that will culminate in the creation of an IsoBank, a web-accessible centralized database of stable isotope data that serves an interdisciplinary research and education community. IsoBank will enable a diverse and rapidly growing scientific community to harness the advantages of big data analytics. At the same time, it will increase the efficiency of a wide range of existing isotope-based applications, which require reference data to support interpretation. IsoBank is envisioned to foster interactions across disciplines that speak a common chemical language that will result in the fusion of diverse perspectives, a process that has resulted in some of the biggest and most creative advances in science. IsoBank will enhance the standards for data quality assurance and control by creating a network among core isotope laboratories in the U.S. that are currently producing nearly a million new datapoints per year. Lastly, IsoBank (isobank.org) is poised to address growing initiatives of publication and funding agencies for data accessibility and transparency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific progress is often viewed as the focused work of specialists; however, increasingly certain types of widely used scientific data bridge the divides between specialist fields and lead to transformative insights. Information such as genetic sequence data, geographic information and stable isotope chemistry data is used by and useful to broad swaths of the researchers, creating opportunities for data sharing and exchange to accelerate scientific discovery across diverse fields. Although standardized protocols and resources for documenting and sharing genetic and geospatial data are well established, the same is not true for stable isotope data. This has limited sharing and reuse of stable isotope data, inhibiting scientific advances that might be supported by open data exchange.

The Intellectual Merit of the IsoBank project centered on the design and development of standards and resources supporting the open sharing of stable isotope data across scientific disciplines. The project team recruited a large and diverse group of experts from multiple fields, including the biological sciences, social and behavioral sciences, Earth and environmental science, and technical specialists in isotope ratio mass spectrometry and computer science, and engaged them in a multi-year design process. The result of these efforts included a standardized structure for stable isotope data and metadata storage that was responsive to the needs of IsoBank’s broad, interdisciplinary stakeholder community. The structure, as well as lists of terms and standards implemented in the structure, was published via the IsoBank website and the scientific literature and was deployed as a prototype database with a simple user-facing web interface. This work demonstrated the potential for single, community-engaged database to support stable isotope data exchange across diverse scientific communities and provided a concrete set of building blocks and standards for the future development and deployment of such a resource.

The Broader Impacts of the project involved community development, engagement, and training centered on IsoBank and open data sharing. The group involved in the IsoBank design process was itself a newly formed collaborative community, consisting of disciplinary experts from multiple fields who were united by a common focus on data archiving and efficient exchange. The development of this community has generated new opportunities for cross-disciplinary science and collaboration. IsoBank also engaged the broader scientific community through a series of in-person and virtual workshops that provided training and a forum for discussion of data sharing needs and practices across multiple fields. Finally, the project helped provide training in data resources for stable isotope science via two internationally recognized graduate summer courses (IsoCamp and SPATIAL), which enrolled several hundred students from across the spectrum of IsoBank-supported fields during the project period.
